description:
Lasiodiplodia theobromae is a fungal plant pathogen that belongs to the class Dothideomycetes, order Botryosphaeriales, and family Botryosphaeriaceae. It is a widely distributed species, known to infect a broad range of host plants, including economically important crops such as cacao, mango, citrus, and various other fruits, vegetables, and woody plants.

The fungus primarily infects plant tissues through wounds or natural openings, causing various disease symptoms, including stem and fruit rot, cankers, dieback, and root rot. It can survive as a saprophyte on plant debris and can also form thick-walled structures called pycnidia, which produce asexual spores (conidia) that can be dispersed by wind, water, or insects.

Lasiodiplodia theobromae is considered an opportunistic pathogen, often taking advantage of stressed or weakened host plants. Its ability to adapt to diverse environmental conditions and its wide host range contribute to its success as a plant pathogen, posing a significant challenge in agricultural and horticultural settings.
